reasoning: The critique targets a moderately central potential equivocation: the post sometimes talks as if the output Y is about capability/superintelligence, but much of the formal discussion maps Y to something like algorithmic efficiency / faster R&D (and later even defines SIE in terms of “effective training compute” gains). If the post truly required showing capability jumps under fixed hardware, this ambiguity would be quite damaging; however, the author’s explicit operationalization of SIE makes the critique only partly central and partly avoidable. The critique is mostly correct that efficiency and capability aren’t interchangeable and that “more efficient experimentation” doesn’t automatically imply “superintelligence,” but it doesn’t engage the author’s likely bridge claim (efficiency/R&D speedups plausibly translate into capability). It is clear, focused, and has little filler.
title: Conflating efficiency gains with capability jumps weakens the singularity argument
